docs.title: Home
docs.text:
Welcome to the CASA theoretical knowledge hub. Everything you need to know regarding Australian ATS phraseology and Standard Operating Procedures can be found here for use on the ATC24 network and even possibly VATSIM. Note the contents of this site are for educational purposes only and should not be used within the real world.

A majority of information within this site is taken from the VATSIM Australia Pacific division's SOPs and training material and the Air Services Australia AIP book and Manual of Air Traffic Services.

docs.title: Components of a clearance
docs.text:
The following items are mandatory components of any airways clearance:

  • Callsign;
  • Clearance Limit;
  • Route of Flight;
  • Altitude;
  • Departure Procedure;
  • Transponder Code; and
  • Frequency

Callsign

It is important to ensure you are giving the right clearance to the right aircraft.

Clearance Limit

This is the point to which the aircraft is cleared to. The aircraft cannot proceed beyond this point without obtaining a new clearance. The clearance limit is always the aircraft's destination aerodrome.

Route of Flight

This is the route the aircraft will fly. The first waypoint and the words FLIGHT PLANNED ROUTE might be used to indicate whether the clearance being granted corresponds with the pilot's filed route. The word "FLIGHT PLANNED ROUTE" can be deleted if the pilot has flown from one aerodrome to another with only one intermediate waypoint.

If an aircraft has planned direct to an aerodrome with no intermediate waypoints, simply clear them 'direct'.

  • Cleared to Rockford, direct

Runway

The departure runway assigned to the pilot should be communicated as part of an airways clearance unless a single runway is nominated on the ATIS for departures or the aircraft is intending to conduct circuits.

Departure Procedure

Aircraft may depart via a visual departure or a SID (Standard Instrument Departure). The majority of IFR aircraft departing a major aerodrome will do so via a SID. VFR aircraft cannot fly SIDs so will be issued with a visual departure.

  • [SID Chart Title] departure

Altitude

This is the initial altitude the pilot has been cleared to after departure. You can find the Standard Assignable level for each aerodrome in the SOPs.

"Climb Via SID"

This phraseology is used to ensure the pilot complies with all speed and level restrictions shown on the SID.

  • CLIMB VIA SID to [Altitude]

Aircraft not assigned a SID shall be given the standard climb instruction.

  • CLIMB to [Altitude]

Transponder Code

The 4 digit code used to uniquely identify the aircraft. Squawk codes only vary between numbers 0-7 (You cannot squawk 8 or higher)

Departure Frequency

This is the frequency the aircraft will contact once airborne after recieving the instruction to 'CONTACT DEPARTURES'.

  • If a TCU controller is online, it will be the most appropriate TCU frequency as per aerodrome SOPs
  • If an enroute sector is online and no TCU controller is online, they are most likely providing top-down coverage and so the departure frequency should be the enroute sector that covers the aerodrome
  • If none of these apply, departures are on advisory 122.800.

docs.title: Phraseology
docs.text:
An airways clearance should always be delivered in the standard format to avoid ambiguity.

Phraseology

QFA251: "Perth Delivery, QFA251 to Rockford, request clearance." PH ACD: "QFA251 Perth Delivery, Cleared to Rockford via CAMEL, flight planned route, CAMEL TWO departure, climb via SID to 2000ft, squawk 2461, departure frequency 135.25." QFA251: "Cleared to Rockford via CAMEL, flight planned route, CAMEL TWO departure, climb via SID to 6000ft, squawk 2461, departure frequency 135.25, Bay 12, QFA251." PH ACD: "QFA251."

Phraseology

QLK113D: "Perth Delivery, QLK113D to Tokyo, request clearance." PH ACD: "QLK113D Perth Delivery, Cleared to Tokyo direct, Runway 33, PERTH TWO departure, climb via SID to 2000ft, squawk 6347, departure frequency 122.8. " QLK113D: "Cleared to Tokyo direct, Runway 33, PERTH TWO departure, climb via SID to 2000ft, squawk 6347, departures 122.8, Bay 24, QLK113D." PH ACD: "QLK113D."

docs.title: Readbacks
docs.text:
After all components have been accurately read back, the delivery controller should respond with the aircraft's callsign alone. Listen to the readback to make sure the pilot has received the information correctly, and correct any errors as soon as possible. This eliminates the need to relay the entire clearance when responding with a correction.

The controller should not respond with the phrase "Readback Correct", as that phraseology is not used in Australia.

docs.title: VFR Aircraft
docs.text:
The handling of VFR aircraft in controlled airspace is frequently misunderstood, however the majority of phraseology actually applies to handling IFR aircraft with a few adjustments. All of the aforementioned information is included in a VFR clearance, however they are not eligible for a SID. When it comes to providing the first altitude and departure process, this is crucial.

Phraseology

PH ACD: "GMO, cleared to Lukla via Stadium, climb to 2000ft, squawk 1271, departure frequency 135.25." GMO: "Cleared to Lukla via Stadium, climb to 2000ft, squawk 1271, departure frequency 135.25, Bay 45, GMO." PH ACD: "GMO. "

docs.title: Activate the FDR
docs.text: Once the airways clearance has been read back correctly, the controller should click the checkbox under the 'C' column within the departure list. This is to signify the aircraft has recieved and correctly understood every component of their clearance.

docs.title: Heads-Up Coordination
docs.text:
Note that some clearances require a heads-up call to the relevant TCU/ENR controller where they will approve the clearance based on current traffic volumes and controller workload. It also gives the TCU controller a chance to change the assigned level or tracking for the aircraft to be delivered in the airways clearance. Refer to aerodrome SOPs on which clearances require coordination.

Phraseology

PH ACD: "YLP requests clearance to Lukla" PH TCU: "YLP clearance approved"

docs.title: Positions
docs.text:
Name Callsign Frequency Login ID Perth ADC Perth Tower 127.400 IPPH_TWR Perth SMC Perth Ground 121.700 IPPH_GND Perth ACD Perth Delivery 118.550 IPPH_DEL

Non-Standard Positions

Non-standard positions may only be opened during events.

docs.title: Airspace
docs.text: PH ADC is not responsible for any airspace by default.

docs.title: Taxiway Restrictions
docs.text:
• Link 1, 2, 3 & 4 are limited to Class C aircraft and above
  • For A380/B747 available routes refer to PH Ground Movement Chart - Page 1

docs.title: Pushback Requests on ACD
docs.text:
During busy periods such as during events, SMC and ACD may coordinate to implement the Pushback Requests on ACD procedure to balance the workload across ACD and SMC frequencies.

When implementing the procedure, there should be some sort of indication to inform pilots the correct frequency on which to request pushback.

docs.title: Scenic Flights
docs.text: When traffic permits, VFR scenic flights should be cleared via the NORTHCOAST SCENIC (FACT-REEL-DOWN) or SOUTHCOAST SCENIC (FACT-STAD-GUAR-PENL) routes. Coordination with PH TCU is required prior to issuing this clearance, see ACD to PH TCU

docs.title: Helicopter Operations
docs.text:
There are no helipad facilities at IPPH. Helicopters should be issued an airways clearance in accordance with the fixed-wing operation applicable to their flight rules (i.e. SID for IFR helicopters, Visual Departure via appropriate VFR route if necessary for VFR helicopters). Helicopters should be cleared to takeoff/land from runways or taxiways, as deemed appropriate by ADC. The point of takeoff/landing must be specified by ADC.

Phraseology

PH ADC: "MRT, taxiway charlie, cleared for takeoff" PH ADC: "HWO, runway 33, cleared to land"

docs.title: Preferred Runway Modes
docs.text:
Subject to wind limitations, single runway operations may be necessary. However, pending wind limitations (Crosswind <20kts, Tailwind <5kts), the following runway modes are to be used:

Mode Arrivals Departures Northwest Plan (29AD/33A) 29 & 33 29 Southeast Plan (11AD/15D) 11 11 & 15

docs.title: Circuit Training
docs.text:
Circuit training traffic shall be issued SSR code and clearance to operate within the circuit area not above A015. Circuit training is typically conducted on Runway 11/29.

Circuit direction should be influenced by the current runway mode currently active. Should single runway operations be in use, circuit direction should conform to the standard (left-hand circuits).

Mode Circuit Direction Northwest Plan Right-hand circuits Southeast Plan Left-hand circuits

docs.title: SID Selection
docs.text: Aircraft planned via HONDA and CAMEL shall be assigned the appropriate Procedural SID that terminates at the appropriate waypoint. Aircraft not planned via any of these waypoints or aircraft with no filed route shall be assigned the Radar SID.

docs.title: Off Mode Departures
docs.text:
Definition

Off Mode: Aircraft departing from a runway not prescribed as active for departures on the ATIS. For example, a heavy aircraft that operationally requires Runway 11/29 during 15/33 single runway operations due to wind limitations.

For aircraft departing Runway 11/29 Off Mode, the Radar SID must be assigned.

Note

Assigning the Radar SID to an off-mode departure does not meet the requirements for auto release. These aircraft must be 'Next' coordinated with PH TCU.

docs.title: Auto Release
docs.text:
Next coordination is not required for aircraft that are:

  • Departing from a runway nominated on the ATIS; and
  • Assigned the standard assignable level; and
  • Assigned a Procedural SID

All other aircraft require a 'Next' call to PH TCU.

The Standard Assignable level from PH ADC to PH TCU is:

Aircraft Level All The lower of A020 and RFL

docs.title: Departures Controller
docs.text:
When a TCU controller is online, aircraft shall be issued with a departure frequency during their airways clearance in accordance with the table below. If no TCU controllers are online, the most appropriate Enroute controller or Advisory frequency shall be issued.

Runway Via Departure Frequency All All 118.7 (PHD)

docs.title: ACD to TCU
docs.text:
The controller assuming responsibility of ACD shall give heads-up coordination to the relevant PH TCU controller prior to the issue of the following clearances:

  • VFR departures into PH TCU CTA
  • Aircraft using a runway not on the ATIS

docs.title: Responsibilities
docs.text:
The primary responsibilities of ADC are to:

  • Apply runway seperation standards to prevent collisions on the runway
  • Apply wake turbulence seperation standards to ensure departing aircraft are not affected by the wake turbulence vortices generated by preceding traffic
  • At many aerodromes, ADC must also manage traffic to prevent collisions in the circuit area

Contrary to popular opinion, ADC control is more than simply issuing takeoff and landing clearances. These are the two most common phrases heard on air, but what you don't hear is the background work required in order to issue those clearances.

docs.title: Runway Seperation
docs.text:
Runway seperation standards require a combination of minimum distances between aircraft and/or certain conditions to be met in order for a takeoff or landing clearance to be issued. Runway seperation standards must be applied between an aircraft:

  • landing behind a preceding landing aircraft
  • landing behind a departing aircraft
  • departing behind a landing aircraft
  • departing behind a preceding departing aircraft

Runway seperation standards in their most simple form require the following:

  • the runway to be clear of other aircraft
  • minimum distances between departures

docs.title: Wake Turbulence Seperation
docs.text: Depending on the weight category of the aircraft, minimum distances or time intervals are required between successive departures. These are calculated to minimise the adverse effect of the wake turbulence vortices created by other traffic.

docs.title: Manage Circuit Traffic
docs.text: At many aerodromes, circuit traffic is managed by ADC rather than TCU. Generally speaking, this involves using a variety of tools & techniques to establish an orderly landing sequence.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
Before clearing a departure for takeoff, ADC must:

  • ensure the aircraft is READY
  • obtain departure instructions from TCU/ENR if applicable
  • check that the runway is clear of other aircraft
  • apply a runway seperation standard with the preceding departure
  • apply wake turbulence seperation with the preceding departure

docs.title: READY call
docs.text:
The READY call serves two purposes: it is used by pilots to establish communications with ADC and notify their preparedness for departure. In other words, there is nothing that will delay the aircraft from commencing its takeoff roll once on the runway. ATC rely on the READY call to estimate timings and work out whether they can get the departure away ahead of the next arrival.

Departing aircraft will contact ADC when READY at or approaching the holding point. If the aircraft does not report ready on initial contact, you should remind them to report when ready.

Phraseology

QFA724: "Perth Tower, QFA724, holding point A5" PH ADC: "QFA724, Perth Tower, report ready" QFA724: "Wilco, QFA724"

On recieving the READY call from an aircraft, the ADC controller has two choices of instructions:

  • LINE UP (AND WAIT)
  • CLEARED FOR TAKEOFF

You may simply acknowledge the aircraft's callsign if you want them to hold short of the runway.

docs.title: Departure Instructions
docs.text: You may recall that there are several types of departure procedures available. Some of these departure procedures require a departure instruction with the takeoff clearance. Coordination will need to be conducted to obtain the desired departure instructions from the TMA controller. Departure instructions should be recorded in the remarks field within the aircraft's strip in the departure list.

docs.title: Auto Release
docs.text: Auto Release is a procedure that allows the ADC controller to clear an aircraft to depart without coordination to the TCU/ENR controller. Since this is a TCU/ENR controller essentially letting aircraft enter their airspace, a number of conditions must be met to enable Auto Release to be used.

docs.title: Coordination
docs.text:
ADC obtains the departure instructions from TCU/ENR through use of the NEXT call. The NEXT call from ADC lets TCU/ENR know that the aircraft is anticipated to be airborne within two minutes. On recieving the NEXT call, TCU/ENR provides departure instructions to ADC, who issues them to the aircraft. The instructions will vary depending on the local procedures, but can be summarised as:

  • a radar heading or direction of turn for a visual departure,
  • an altitude restriction, or
  • The phrase "UNRESTRICTED" if there is no restriction to the initial altitude issued in the airways clearance. It does not mean ADC can climb a departure to their planned/requested level.

ADC will then issue the departure instructions to the aircraft.

Phraseology

PH ADC: ASSIGNED HEADING LEFT/RIGHT (three digits) OR PH ADC: TRACK EXTENDED RUNWAY CENTRELINE (three digits) DEGREES OR PH ADC: TURN LEFT/RIGHT HEADING (three digits) VISUAL OR PH ADC: MAKE LEFT/RIGHT TURN

Phraseology

PH ADC: "NEXT, QFA125" PH TCU: "QFA125, left heading 320, UNRESTRICTED" PH ADC: "QFA125, assigned heading left 320, cleared for takeoff"

docs.title: Line Up [And Wait] Instruction
docs.text:
The instruction to LINE UP authorises an aircraft to enter the runway and align with the runway centreline. Aircraft must not commence take off unless issued with CLEARED FOR TAKEOFF. A LINE UP instruction is used when a take off clearance cannot be immediately issued but it is anticipated that there will be no delay on the runway.

The further instruction AND WAIT indicates to the pilot that there will be a delay in the lined up position. It is used to emphasise that a take off clearance will not be issued straight away. The use of conditional clearances for line up and wait instructions is no longer used within Australia and thus should not be used. Simply wait until the arriving aircraft has passed the runway holding point of the departing aircraft then issue the instruction.

docs.title: Take off behind a previous departure
docs.text:
Do not clear an aircraft for take off until the preceding departure is airborne and has:

  • passed the upwind threshold of the runway; or
  • commenced a turn

docs.title: Take off behind previous arrival
docs.text: Do not clear an aircraft for take off until the preceding arrival has vacated the runway fully.

docs.title: Intersecting runway operations
docs.text: Do not clear an aircraft to take off or land until a departing aircraft on the crossing runway has crossed the intersection, or an arriving aircraft has either crossed the intersection or landed and stopped short of the intersection.

docs.title: Issue Take Off Clearance
docs.text:
Phraseology

PH ADC: "QFA12, cleared for takeoff" PH ADC: "QFA12, runway 29 cleared for takeoff" PH ADC: "QFA12, assigned heading left 220, runway 29 cleared for takeoff"

docs.title: Traffic Information
docs.text:
Traffic information can be issued with a takeoff clearance where the controller deems it necessary, e.g. aircraft joining the circuit with another aircraft already in the circuit.

Phraseology

PH ADC: "GBT, traffic is a Cessna 172 on crosswind remaining in the circuit, runway 29 cleared for takeoff"

docs.title: Frequency Transfer
docs.text:
In most cases, a pilot will need to change to the Departures frequency shortly after takeoff. This can be included in the takeoff clearance or in a seperate instruction once the aircraft has been observed to be airborne. When no departure service is available the aircraft should be approved to change frequency to the advisory frequency.

Phraseology

PH ADC: "QFA621 contact departures" PH ADC: "QFA71, frequency change approved"

docs.title: What is an ATIS?
docs.text:
An Automatic Terminal Information Service (ATIS) is a recorded audio loop of operational and weather information for a controlled aerodrome. When approaching or departing a controlled aerodrome, pilots tune to a designated radio frequency to listen to the recording. It provides information about:

  • The type of approach to expect
  • The runway(s) in use
  • Current weather conditions
  • Any other relevant operational information

Note that due to limitations with discord/Roblox, ATC24 provides an ATIS in text form for pilots to read.

docs.title: Updating an ATIS
docs.text:
The METAR within PTFS gets updated pretty often and so it is up to you when to update the ATIS, however in the real world, ATIS changes are subject to changes in meterological and operational conditions described below. Every time you update an ATIS, a new code letter should be issued.

  • The requirement for, or type of, instrument approach is changed
  • Changes occur to a traffic management initiative e.g. LAHSO
  • The take-off or landing runway is changed
  • Changes occur in the operational status of an aerodrome
  • Current values of meterological information vary by, or exceed, the values in the table below:
MET Information Variation Wind Direction 10° or Speed 5 kt QNH 1 Hectopascal (HPA) Temperature 1°

docs.title: Broadcasting ATIS changes on frequency
docs.text:
Whenever a new ATIS is released, the changes must be broadcast on SMC and ACD frequencies.

Phraseology

PH SMC: "All stations, information Kilo is now current. The changes, Wind 210 degrees 11 knots, maximum crosswind 12 knots, QNH 1015. Changes Perth information Kilo."

docs.title: Purpose
docs.text: During pushback, an aircraft moves from a parking position onto the manoeuvring area. This represents a movement into what is considered an 'active' area and is why aircraft request authorisation from the relevant SMC controller before carrying out the procedure. When a pushback request is recieved, the ground controller should consider other active traffic and provide any relevant traffic information along with the approval.

docs.title: Phraseology
docs.text:
Phraseology

QTR25K: "Perth Ground, QTR25K Super, Bay 15, request pushback" PH SMC: "QTR25K Super, Perth Ground, pushback approved" QTR25K: "Push approved, QTR25K"

Phraseology

QFA349: "Perth Ground, QFA349, Bay 14, request pushback" PH SMC: "QFA349, Perth Ground, pushback approved, traffic is a company 737 on Tango Lane" QFA349: "Pushback approved, traffic in sight, QFA349" PH SMC: "QFA287, traffic is a company 737 pushing back in front of you" QFA287: "QFA287 traffic in sight"

Traffic Information

Note that directed traffic information should always be passed to both parties involved. If traffic information is given to the aircraft pushing back, it should also be provided to the other traffic. There is no requirement to provide seperation instructions to either aircraft as collision avoidance are the pilots and ground crew's responsibility.

docs.title: Start Clearance
docs.text: Start clearance is required for aircraft to begin engine start procedures should local SOPs dictate. This is usually requested along with pushback since most commercial airliners start their engines during pushback.

docs.title: Procedure
docs.text:
Previously we learnt that a ground controller's area of responsibility does not include runways, even if the runway is inactive, and that we must first coordinate with Tower before instructing an aircraft to taxi across, enter or back track a runway. This coordination should occur in a timely fashion, just prior to the aircraft reaching the runway.

When coordinating with Tower, there are three key items that must be used.

  • Aircraft Type: A320, B737, B777, A380, etc
  • Location: Taxiway the aircraft is currently on
  • Runway: The runway the aircraft will enter, back track or cross

Phraseology

PH SMC: "B737 at Delta Two to cross Runway 33" PH ADC: "B737 at Delta Two cross Runway 33" OR PH ADC: "Negative, Hold Short"

Tower should respond with one of the above, providing a hold short instruction if the request is unable to be approved. Ground should ensure they read back the instruction to Tower, using the following phraseology:

Phraseology

PH SMC: "Cross Runway 33 at Delta Two"

docs.title: Runway Release
docs.text:
A runway release is the process of releasing a non active runway from Tower to Ground, this reduces the workload of both controllers by allowing Ground to instruct aircraft to cross or otherwise use the non-active runway without having to coordinate with Tower.

Phraseology

PH SMC: "Request Runway 33 release to Ground" PH ADC: "Runway 33 released to Ground"

Note that Tower can recall a runway release immediately. Upon recall, Ground shall acknowledge the recall with a traffic statement:

Phraseology

PH SMC: "Runway 33, No traffic" OR PH SMC: "Runway 33, Traffic is a Qantas 747 crossing at Delta Two"

docs.title: ADC Offline
docs.text:
When controlling SMC with ADC offline, the runways have not been released to SMC, they are uncontrolled. This means traffic is permitted to use the runway for landing/takeoff without permission of the SMC controller. Any aircraft that requires to cross a runway shall be given a traffic statement as follows:

Phraseology

PH SMC: "QFA261, Cross Runway 33 at your discretion, no reported or observed traffic" OR PH SMC: "QFA261, Cross Runway 33 at your discretion, traffic observed on a 5nm final, callsign is UAL9125"

docs.title: Responsibilities
docs.text:
The primary responsibility of the SMC controller is to prevent collisions between aircraft on the ground. This is done through issuing taxi instructions to regulate and control the movement of aircraft within the manoeuvring area. The secondary responsibility of the SMC controller is to maintain an orderly and efficient flow of traffic on the ground through careful planning of taxi routes and analysing traffic priorities to minimise delays. Typical duties for SMC include:

  • issuing taxi clearances
  • issuing pushback approvals and providing traffic information
  • coordinating runway crossings for taxiing aircraft

docs.title: Collision Avoidance
docs.text:
ATC responsibility for collision avoidance only covers parts of the aerodrome used for take-off, landing and taxiing of aircraft, excluding aprons and parking areas. This is known as the manoeuvring area. ATC is not responsible for aircraft operations on aprons, parking areas or any other area outside the manoeuvring area. Therefore, an ATC clearance is not required to operate on these areas.

On the manoeuvring area, collision avoidance is a joint pilot-controller responsibility whereas beyond the manoeuvring area it is the responsibility of the pilot and any assisting ground personnel. ATC will help by providing traffic information about other aircraft entering or leaving the same apron or parking area.

docs.title: Pushback
docs.text:
Aircraft will usually start their engines during or shortly after pushback. Clearance to start engines is not normally required from ATC unless outlined in local procedures. Aircraft must request pushback approval from SMC. SMC will issue the approval whilst taking into account other moving traffic and provide traffic information where necessary. The pilot and assisting ground crew are then responsible for collision avoidance during the pushback sequence.

Pushback approval may be withheld to regulate the entry of aircraft onto the taxiways during busy periods. This is important at some locations where aircraft pushback directly onto taxiways. Withholding approval can also assist in maintaining an efficient flow of traffic across the aerodrome.

docs.title: Regulating Traffic Flow
docs.text:
While the primary responsibility is to prevent collisions, the secondary responsibility is the orderly flow of traffic around the aerodrome. This is the responsibility of SMC, who must come up with a plan to get the arrivals to the gate and departures to the holding point with minimal delay.

It requires a 'big picture' approach, such as familiarity with the available taxi routes, holding points and required runway crossings. Prioritising arrivals over departures is important and will assist your decision making. Traffic can be regulated through the use of progressive taxi instructions, holding departures on the apron, and instructing aircraft to give way or follow other aircraft.

docs.title: Structure and Phraseology
docs.text:
When issuing taxi instructions, correct structure and phraseology ensure that the correct route is followed by the pilot and runway incursions are prevented. You must provide concise taxi instructions that:

  • Give adequate information to assist pilots in determining correct taxi routes and avoid collisions with other aircraft or obstructions, and;
  • Regulate entry to and movement on taxiways

Regardless of the type of taxi instruction you issue, you must always issue a taxi limit. The taxi limit can be a runway holding point, or an intersection where two taxiways meet. Depending on the traffic situation, you may elect to issue a simple taxi clearance or outline the taxi clearance precisely to avoid aircraft turning onto the wrong taxiways and ending up nose-to-nose with another aircraft.

Phraseology

QFA625: "QFA625 recieved Bravo, request taxi" PH SMC: "QFA625 taxi to holding point Echo, Runway 33" QFA625: "Taxi to holding point Echo, Runway 33, QFA625"

Phraseology

UAE21: "UAE21 Heavy, recieved Mike, request taxi" PH SMC: "UAE21 Heavy, taxi Delta, Echo, holding point Echo, Runway 33" UAE21: "Taxi Delta, Echo, holding point Echo Runway 33, UAE21"

docs.title: Phraseology don'ts
docs.text:
• Don't use the word 'cleared' when issuing taxi instructions and runway crossings, A taxi instruction is just that - an instruction, not a clearance.
  • Don't refer to both designations of a runway (e.g. "cross Runway 11/29"). Only refer to the 'active-end' of a runway in an instruction. If the runway is not in use, just choose the most into the wind designation and be consistent.

docs.title: Hold Short / Cross Runway Instructions
docs.text:
A taxi instruction that contains a taxi limit beyond a runway must include a "CROSS RUNWAY (number)" instruction. But before we can issue this, SMC must first get permission from the ADC to allow the aircraft to use/cross the runway, even if the runway is not active. Coordination phraseology will be discussed further in. If permission to cross the runway is not available when the aircraft calls for taxi, the aircraft must be issued a taxi limit of the holding point associated with the intersecting runway along the taxi route. Taxi instructions must not include a position beyond that of a required intermediate holding point.

Taxiing aircraft must be issued with an instruction to "CROSS RUNWAY (number)" if previously issued with;

  1. A taxi instruction limit of the holding point of a runway intersecting the taxi route; or
  2. An instruction to "HOLD SHORT" of a runway.

Phraseology

PH SMC: "SIA2374, taxi Delta Two, cross Runway 33, Alpha, holding point Alpha Five, Runway 29" SIA2374: "Taxi Delta Two, cross Runway 33, Alpha, holding point Alpha Five, Runway 29, SIA2374"

Phraseology

PH SMC: "QFA520, taxi Delta Two, hold short Runway 33" QFA520: "Taxi Delta Two, hold short Runway 33, QFA520"

docs.title: Controlling the Flow of Ground Traffic
Intermediate Hold Short / Give Way / Follow
docs.text:
Issuing intermediate hold short instructions allows you to establish positive seperation on the ground, by instructing an aircraft to hold short of a specific taxiway, where aircraft may need to cross paths. This then becomes a taxi limit, the aircraft cannot taxi further without recieving a new taxi instruction from the controller, and ground seperation is maintained. Instructing aircraft to "GIVE WAY" or "FOLLOW" will reduce controller workload, and keep the flow of traffic moving, while allowing pilots to establish their own seperation on the ground.

Phraseology

PH SMC: "QLK2151, give way to the Emirates 777 on Tango Lane, hold short Runway 33" PH SMC: "DLH25EY, follow the Qantas 380 on Tango Lane"

docs.title: When to explicitly transfer an aircraft?
docs.text:
Once an aircraft is at the runway holding point, the SMC controller is no longer relevant for the aircraft - only ADC can clear the aircraft to either enter an active runway, or takeoff. In Australia, most domestic aircraft will independently contact the tower once at or approaching the holding point. For international aircraft, who may not be as familiar with local procedures, an explicit transfer is required. In the absence of ADC being online, aircraft at the holding point shall be instructed to monitor advisory on 122.8

Note

Pilots on the ATC24 network and even on VATSIM are not aware of their duty to contact the tower controller autonomously and so it is best practice to provide an explicit frequency transfer to all departing aircraft. The main thing is to be consistent. You don't want an aircraft sitting idle at the holding point awaiting a frequency transfer from you.

Phraseology

PH SMC: "UAL2915, contact tower 124.7" UAL2915: "Tower 124.7, UAL2915" OR PH SMC: "QFA844, at the holding point, contact tower 124.7" QFA844: "Wilco, QFA844"

Ensure that you no longer need to have contact with the aircraft before this transfer, and that you have seperation assurance guaranteed all the way to the holding point.
